educationPrograms.title: Lotus Pedals
educationPrograms.description: Provides bicycles to girls who live far from school, helping them attend classes regularly and safely.
educationPrograms.fullDescription: The Lotus Pedals program addresses one of the most significant barriers to education for girls in rural Cambodia: transportation. Many girls live several kilometers away from their schools, making the daily journey on foot both time-consuming and potentially dangerous. By providing sturdy, reliable bicycles, we enable these young women to attend school regularly, arrive safely, and have more time for their studies and family responsibilities.
features: High-quality, durable bicycles designed for rural terrain
Safety training and helmet provision
Maintenance workshops for recipients
Community engagement to ensure program sustainability
Follow-up support to track educational outcomes

educationPrograms.title: Rice for Education
educationPrograms.description: Supplies monthly rice and food support to families of scholarship girls, helping reduce school dropouts due to household economic pressures.
educationPrograms.fullDescription: Lotus Outreach Cambodia's "Rice for Education" (R4E) program is a vital initiative aimed at reducing school dropout rates among girls from economically disadvantaged families. By providing monthly rice and food support, the program alleviates household food insecurity, allowing families to prioritize their daughters' education without the added pressure of daily survival.
features: Full educational scholarships covering tuition and supplies
Monthly rice distributions to families
Academic mentoring and tutoring support
Life skills training and counseling
Career guidance and job placement assistance

educationPrograms.title: CATALYST
educationPrograms.description: (CAmbodian TertiAry Education And Leadership YouTh) a university scholarship and leadership development program for GATE graduates.
educationPrograms.fullDescription: CATALYST is our flagship leadership development program that transforms promising young women into confident leaders and change-makers in their communities. Through comprehensive university scholarships, intensive mentoring, and specialized leadership training, CATALYST participants develop the skills, knowledge, and networks needed to break cycles of poverty and become advocates for positive change in Cambodia.
features: Full university scholarships including living expenses
One-on-one mentoring with successful professionals
Leadership workshops and public speaking training
Internship opportunities with partner organizations
Alumni network and ongoing career support

educationPrograms.title: PNC/V
educationPrograms.description: Providing high-quality IT education in a holistic residential environment for at-risk female youth in Cambodia and Vietnam.
educationPrograms.fullDescription: The Passerelles Numériques Cambodia/Vietnam program offers intensive, industry-relevant IT education to disadvantaged young women in a supportive residential setting. This comprehensive program combines technical training with personal development, preparing graduates for successful careers in the rapidly growing technology sector while fostering personal growth and leadership skills.
features: Comprehensive IT curriculum covering programming, web development, and digital marketing
Residential program providing safe, supportive living environment
Industry partnerships for internships and job placement
English language training and soft skills development
Ongoing alumni support and career advancement opportunities

communityPrograms.title: Getting Well
communityPrograms.description: Constructing water wells to serve entire villages in drought-prone regions of rural Cambodia.
communityPrograms.fullDescription: The Getting Well program addresses the critical water shortage crisis in rural Cambodia by constructing deep-water wells that provide clean, reliable water access to entire villages. These wells are strategically placed to serve the maximum number of families while considering factors such as water table depth, community needs, and long-term sustainability. Each well project includes community training on maintenance and water management.
features: Deep-water well construction using modern drilling techniques
Solar-powered pumping systems for sustainable operation
Community water management training
Regular maintenance and quality testing programs
Emergency repair services and spare parts provision

communityPrograms.title: Water In Schools (WINS)
communityPrograms.description: Installing water filtration systems in schools to provide clean drinking water and improve wellbeing for children in rural Cambodia.
communityPrograms.fullDescription: The Water In Schools (WINS) program ensures that students have access to clean, safe drinking water throughout their school day. By installing advanced water filtration systems in rural schools, we eliminate waterborne diseases, improve student health and attendance, and create better learning environments. The program also includes hygiene education to maximize health benefits.
features: Advanced multi-stage water filtration systems
Regular filter replacement and system maintenance
Hygiene education programs for students and teachers
Water quality testing and monitoring
Community involvement in system oversight

communityPrograms.title: Rice 4 Education (R4E)
communityPrograms.description: Providing rice support to villagers to help them support their daughters' education in rural Cambodia.
communityPrograms.fullDescription: Rice 4 Education recognizes that food security is fundamental to educational access. Many families in rural Cambodia face the difficult choice between sending their children to work or to school. By providing monthly rice distributions to families who commit to keeping their daughters in school, R4E removes this barrier and ensures that education remains a priority even during times of economic hardship.
features: Monthly rice distributions to participating families
School attendance monitoring and reporting
Family education on nutrition and child development
Community engagement and awareness programs
Graduation ceremonies and recognition events

communityPrograms.title: CTC
communityPrograms.description: Providing trauma therapy and assistance to survivors of trafficking and sexual and domestic violence in a women's shelter in rural Cambodia.
communityPrograms.fullDescription: The Counseling and Training Center (CTC) provides comprehensive support services to women and girls who have survived trafficking, sexual violence, and domestic abuse. Located in a safe, residential facility, CTC offers trauma-informed therapy, life skills training, and reintegration support to help survivors heal and rebuild their lives with dignity and independence.
features: Professional trauma counseling and therapy services
Safe residential accommodation and 24/7 support
Vocational training and job placement assistance
Legal advocacy and court accompaniment
Family mediation and community reintegration support

trainingPrograms.title: Life skills and soft skills training
trainingPrograms.description: Lotus Outreach Cambodia offers integrated life skills and soft skills training through holistic programs—like GATE, CATALYST, Lotus Pedals, and reintegration initiatives—that equip vulnerable girls and young women with education.
trainingPrograms.fullDescription: Students participate in a wide range of trainings covering essential topics such as self-awareness, goal setting, time management, communication, problem solving, emotional intelligence, financial literacy, personal safety, reproductive health, leadership, team building, gender awareness, public speaking, and more. These sessions help equip them with the tools needed to thrive academically, socially, and professionally.

During exposure visits and field activities, team leaders are also chosen to coordinate tasks and support their peers, building real-world leadership experience.

trainingPrograms.title: Career and major selection workshops
trainingPrograms.description: These workshops are often led by trained counselors who work one-to-one with students to build a “life project” covering both personal and career development.
trainingPrograms.fullDescription: Lotus Outreach Cambodia and its partners (like Cambodian Women’s Crisis Center) conduct career orientation workshops for high school girls under the GATE program. These sessions aim to introduce students to different educational and vocational pathways and help them explore options beyond secondary school. CATALYST workshops focus on personalized major and education planning, scholarship applications, and building personal goals. Ongoing life project counseling ensures academic planning is paired with self-development, leadership, and advocacy goals.

trainingPrograms.title: Job readiness and exposure visits
trainingPrograms.description: Career readiness workshops, stress management, life project guidance, mentoring. Vocational + life skills, job placement support, micro-enterprise guidance.
trainingPrograms.fullDescription: Scholars participate in mentoring workshops that cover career preparedness, professional development, job interview skills, and workplace readiness. These build critical competencies such as communication, leadership, and life skills alongside academic planning. Counselors help each student develop a personal “life project”, structured around long-term career and personal goals. Participants in NFE—many of whom have left or are exiting red-light venues—receive vocational training such as sewing, cooking, beauty, or handicrafts. After completing training, Lotus Outreach assists graduates in job placement or micro‑enterprise creation, supporting a transition out of high-risk sectors. Follow-ups help sustain reintegration.

trainingPrograms.title: Meet the Leaders Who Inspired a Generation
trainingPrograms.description: Mrs. Chanthol Oung – Executive Director, Women’s Media Centre of Cambodia (WMC)
trainingPrograms.fullDescription: With more than two decades of leadership experience, Mrs. Chanthol brought wisdom from both national and international service. She previously served as Technical Director of the Arbitration Council Foundation (Cambodia) and worked in the U.S. as a police liaison with STAND! and as a program coordinator with the Cambodia Association of America. She also co-founded the Cambodian Women’s Crisis Center and worked with UNHCHR, the Human Rights Task Force, and UNTAC during Cambodia’s historic elections. She holds a Ph.D. in Public Policy (USA), a Master's in International Human Rights Law (Hong Kong), and a Law degree (Thailand).

trainingPrograms.title: Overcoming challenges through perseverance and proving your worth through action
trainingPrograms.description: Mr. Chea Bunseang – CEO, Bunseang Architects and Associates
trainingPrograms.fullDescription: As one of Cambodia’s most respected architects, Mr. Bunseang holds a Master's in Urban Environmental Management from the Asian Institute of Technology. He previously worked with UN-Habitat, the UN Mission in East Timor, and as a consultant for World Bank development projects. He later studied and worked in the United States, overcoming language barriers and racism before returning home to found his own design firm. He encouraged participants to rise above setbacks: “I was judged for how I looked and how I spoke. But hard work, self-discipline, and being proactive helped people see my value—not just my limitations.”

trainingPrograms.title: What Students Took Away: Lessons That Stick
trainingPrograms.description: The Q&A sessions opened up powerful discussions. Panelists emphasized that soft skills—such as communication, adaptability, and emotional intelligence—are more essential than technical knowledge when it comes to leadership.
trainingPrograms.fullDescription: Participants left with clarity, courage, and a deeper understanding of what it means to lead with purpose. The impact was clear in the students’ heartfelt reflections. Here’s what they said: “The speakers gave us practical tools and real examples. I was especially inspired by Ms. Sovuthika’s strength. Her confidence taught me that we should never see ourselves as limited.” – Chhoun Sreymoon, CATALYST Scholar “Mrs. Chanthol’s life story touched me deeply. Despite many obstacles, she fought to help others. I hope to follow in her footsteps one day—and maybe study at Harvard like she did.” – Neat Sreynich “The panel helped me understand leadership more clearly. It’s not about being the boss, it’s about listening, problem-solving, setting an example, and growing with your team.” – Khav Synan “Mrs. Ra Ya’s journey was heartbreaking but empowering. She never let poverty or gender stop her. I respect her so much.” – Beot Phanith, Year 3, Accounting “I’ve learned that leaders aren’t born—they’re shaped. Soft skills like communication, attitude, and integrity matter more than degrees.” – Chan Phanny, Year 1, Business Administration “The session helped me understand how to lead myself first—how to make decisions, solve problems, and take responsibility.” – Lyna Hoeun, Year 2, English Literature
features: I learned how to be self-reliant.
We all face challenges, but we can choose how we respond.
Leadership means lifting others up, not just leading from the top.
Hearing about gender discrimination reminded me to never underestimate myself as a woman.
I learned to never underestimate someone’s potential, no matter their background or education.
I realized that a good leader is someone who uplifts others while staying humble
I now believe that gender, poverty, or a painful past doesn’t have to define who we become
I was inspired to use my voice to speak out against injustice and break harmful stereotypes.

givingPrograms.title: Supporting 100 Children in Prey Nup
givingPrograms.description: A charity event organized by CATALYST students and alumni to support 100 underserved children in Prey Nup District with school materials and hygiene supplies.
givingPrograms.fullDescription: On March 16, 2025, Lotus Outreach Cambodia, in collaboration with Let Us Create Futures and local authorities, successfully hosted its 6th Giving Back Event in Prey Nup District, Preah Sihanouk Province. This annual initiative, driven by the leadership of CATALYST students and alumni, is dedicated to fostering a culture of community service among young women. The event aimed to uplift children in need through the distribution of essential school materials, food, and hygiene products. It also empowered students to develop leadership, teamwork, and advocacy skills while creating a joyful and educational experience for the children.
features: Supported 100 children with school bags, notebooks, pens, pencils, erasers, rulers, whiteboards, milk, snacks, bottled water, and soap
Donated food supplies (noodles, canned fish, sauces, tea, sugar) and 100,000 riels to Prey Nup Pagoda monks
Contributed storybooks and second-hand clothes to Let Us Create Futures
Conducted hygiene education and fun learning activities for children
Raised a total of $1,256.96 for the event through generous donor support

givingPrograms.title: Peer mentoring and tutoring
givingPrograms.description: CATALYST scholars tutor and mentor younger GATE students across Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, and rural areas.
givingPrograms.fullDescription: In the CATALYST program, older scholars who were once GATE recipients actively mentor younger GATE students. They help with academic challenges, share strategies for managing university life, and support study habits—creating a structured peer-to-peer guidance network. This mentorship continues through counseling and workshops where experienced students pass on key knowledge about coursework, time management, and navigating scholarship programs in Cambodia.
features: Older or more advanced students mentor younger peers in academics and life skills
Focused help in subjects where students struggle, improving academic performance
Mentors build leadership, empathy, and teaching skills while guiding others
Mentees gain confidence through personalized learning and encouragement
Fosters a supportive, non-judgmental space for asking questions and making mistakes

givingPrograms.title: Community outreach and service projects
givingPrograms.description: Scholars organize and lead giving-back visits to remote schools in provinces like Mondolkiri, Takeo, Siem Reap.
givingPrograms.fullDescription: Each year, CATALYST scholars lead Giving Back Projects in rural Cambodian provinces like Mondolkiri, Takeo, Siem Reap, and Pallin. They plan fundraising, supply school materials, and organize interactive learning sessions for children. Examples include distributing backpacks, notebooks, hygiene essentials, snacks, and water to 80+ children at Bu Rang Elementary School in Mondolkiri (Feb 2024). Scholars also led play-based learning and sanitation lessons.
features: Students participate directly in local service initiatives that address real community needs
Builds leadership, responsibility, and civic awareness among young participants
Enhances problem-solving, teamwork, communication, and project planning skills
Encourages understanding of social justice, inequality, and local development issues
Projects are often coordinated with schools, NGOs, and local authorities for broader impact

givingPrograms.title: Sharing knowledge with junior students
givingPrograms.description: Scholars run educational activities—sanitation, games, storytelling—for younger students during outreach.
givingPrograms.fullDescription: During outreach visits, CATALYST scholars facilitate educational and recreational activities such as storytelling, sanitation workshops, coloring sessions, and games. These create learning environments where younger students are taught by role models from similar backgrounds. This direct engagement empowers scholars to build facilitation, leadership, and communication skills while positively impacting primary-age students in under-resourced schools.
features: Mentors build confidence through teaching; mentees feel safe and encouraged to ask questions
Conducted through flexible methods like group discussions, one-on-one support, or informal workshops
Junior students are inspired by relatable mentors, improving motivation and aspiration
Builds a strong, caring student community where knowledge-sharing is normalized and valued
Encourages senior students to develop public speaking, mentorship, and responsibility

givingPrograms.title: Supporting the next generation of scholarship recipients
givingPrograms.description: Fundraising by scholars and alumni to support incoming GATE recipients; alumni mentoring network established.
givingPrograms.fullDescription: CATALYST scholars often raise funds to support new scholarship recipients—for example, in 2024 they exceeded their modest $550 goal by raising over $1,313 to aid 81 young children in Mondolkiri with school supplies and hygiene items. Additionally, an Alumni Association of GATE and CATALYST graduates (elected into committees in 2020) fosters mentorship of incoming students, community outreach, and coordinated fundraising to sustain the scholarship pipeline.
features: Existing recipients guide new or incoming students, offering practical advice and encouragement
Encourages long-term peer connections and a sense of responsibility to “pay it forward.”
Current recipients develop leadership and communication skills by actively supporting others
Helps new recipients adjust to academic, personal, and program expectations more easily
Fosters a strong sense of identity, unity, and pride within the scholarship community
